div1.p: HE'S MUCH TO BLAME, A COMEDY: IN FIVE ACTS.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER ROW.

div1.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div1.p: THE author of HE'S MUCH TO BLAME is in some small degree indebted to Le Complaisant, a comedy attributed to Monsieur De Ferriol Pont-de-Veyle, and to the tragedy of Clavigo by Goethe.

lg.l: PROLOGUES, in these sagacious days, must not
Repeat the story; and betray the plot:
For deep laid plots we sometimes have, no doubt:
'Tis pity you can't always find them out:
The secret must be kept; and not be told:
In this, at least, we beat the bards of old:
We can't endure our meaning you should guess,
And here again we boast complete success:
Cautious lest you the mystery should discover,
We keep you in the dark—till all is over.
Since these important points we must not name,
The title let's discuss: He's much▪to blame!
To blame? Ay, surely; very much! But who.
The author. Well, that's nothing very new.
And what does blame induce? Why punishment.
Rashly we sin and leisurely repent.
Lured by that tempting bait a nine nights' bonus,
These scribbling sinners multiply upon us!
Then prologues write; to whine, cajole, and tickle:
Begging you'll burn the rod you've laid in pickle.
Shielding himself by these and such like arts,
He hopes to hurl with surer aim his darts.
But strike and cry, when we receive a blow,
Is arrant cowardice! I told him so.
He's mad, who would the field of battle tread;
Unless he hoped to have a broken head.
There's honor in such scars—he'll win and wear it▪
Then give him honor plenty! Never spare it.
But, should it be your pleasure not to quarrel,
He'll very kindly bear his load of laurel.

div1.head: HE'S MUCH TO BLAME, A COMEDY.

div3.head: SCENE I.— Ringing heard. The hall of a hotel, with a spacious stair-case.
div3.stage: Enter the MASTER and HEAD WAITER meeting.

sp.speaker: MASTER.
sp.p: WHY where are all the fellows, Jenkins? Don't you hear the bell No. 9?

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Tom is gone up to answer it, sir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Who occupies that apartment?

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: The handsome youth and girl, that arrived late last night.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Just as I was going to bed?

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: He is quite a boy.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Razor has never robbed him of a hair.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Some stripling, perhaps, that has run away with his mother's maid.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: They ordered separate beds.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Well, see what they want.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p:
And, harkye, be attentive the moment you hear Lord and Lady Vibrate, or their daughter,
stirring. People of quality must never be neglected.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Oh, no, sir—Here is Dr. Gosterman.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Good morrow, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Coot morgen, my tear friend. Is de Fiprate family fisible to see?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My lordtship und my latyship vas sharge me to be mit dem betime.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: You are a great favourite there, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. Dat I am efery vhere.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: You act in a double capacity: physician, and privy counsellor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und I am as better in de von as in de oder.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Why ay, Doctor, you have a smooth pleasant manner.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. Dat is my vay. I mix de syrup mit all my prescription.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you are a useful person.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. Dat is my vay. I leave Yarmany und I com at Englandt mit little money, und great cunning in de art, und de science. I shall af de essence, und de cream, und de balsam, und de syrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earse, und de sea, und all dat vas subject under my command. So I make de nation benefit▪ und myself rish. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Yes; you can tickle the guineas into your pocket.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: You have had many patients?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. I af cure tousand und tousand! Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: And how many have you killed, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Der Teufel, sair! Kill? Ven my patient vas die, dat vas Nature dat vas kill. Ven dey vas cure, dat vas Dr. Von Gostermans. Dat is my vay. No, sair! Dr. Von Gostermans vas kill himself, dat oder people may live.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: How do you mean kill yourself, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Der Teufel, sair! Vas I not be call here? Vas I not be call dere? Vas I not be call efery vhere? I af hundert und tousand patient dat die efery day, till I vas com. So I vas drive to de city; und dere I vas meet my besten friend, de gout, de apoplexy, und de asthmatica: und den I vas drive to de inn of court, und de lawyer; und dere I vas find more of my besten friend; de hydropica, de rheumatica, und de paralytica.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: What, Doctor! The lawyers and inns of court paralytic?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: I wish they were, with all my soul!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und den I vas drive und make my reverence mit de lordt, und mit de duke, und mit de grandee; und dere I vas meet mosh oder of my besten friend; de hypochondrica, de spasmodica, de hysterica, de marasma, de morbid affection, de tremor, und de mist before de eye.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Morbid affections, tremors, and mists before the eyes, the diseases of the great?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. Und dey vas grow vorse und vorse efery day.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Well, well, they have chosen a skilful doctor!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Ya, sair. I shall do all deir business, efery
von. Dat is my vay. I shall af de essence, und de cream, und de balsam, und de syrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earse, und de sea, und all dat vas subject under my command. Dat is my vay. Bote dat is as noting at all. Ah sa, my liebste: you vas my besten friend. You make me acquaint myself mit all de patient dat vas come to your house; and so I vas your besten friend, und I vas gif de physic for yourself, und de physic for your shile, und de physic for your vife.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: For which my wife will never more thank you, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: No: your vife vas die, und you vas tank me yourself. So now you tell me: Af you any new customer dat vas com?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Yes: a youth, and a girl that looks like a waiting maid, arrived late last night.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vhich it vas a person of grandeur?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Oh no; wholly unattended.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ah! Vhich it vas a lofing couple, den?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: It seems not.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: A poy und a vaiting vomans! Dere shall be someting mystery in dat.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: So I think. Here comes the girl.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ah! Let me do: I shall talk to her. I shall begin by make acquaintance mit her.

div3.head: SCENE III. Enter LUCY down the staircase.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Pray, sir, desire the waiter to make haste with breakfast.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Here, Jenkins! Breakfast to No. 9! Be quick!

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: (Without) Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Tea or coffee, madam?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Tea.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: How you do, my tear? You vas pretty young frau: fery pretty girl, my tear. Perhaps you vas stranger, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Perhaps I am.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah! Vat is your name, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That which my Godmother gave me.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Your mastair af made de long yourney, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Has he?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: From vat country you com, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I ask, from vat country you com, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Ask again.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: From de town of—Ha!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Ay. How do you call it?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is vat I vant you shall tell?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I see you do.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Your mastair is fery young, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: For vat you tank me?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: For your news.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah, ah! You are fery vitty und pretty, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: More news. Thank you again.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vat vas you call de young yentleman's name?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I will ask, and send you word.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: How long shall he be stay in town?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Till he goes into the country.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vat is your capacity, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Like yours, little enough.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: You not understandt me, my tear. Vat is your post, your office?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: To answer rude questions.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Your mastair is man of family?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Yes. He had a father, and mother, and uncles, and aunts.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und tey vas tead?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I am not a tombstone.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Com, com, my tear, let you make me answer.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Anan?

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: Here is the breakfast, madam.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Take it up stairs.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Lucy and Waiter up the staircase.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Der Teufel! A cunning yipsey! She has make me raise my curiosity. (Calls.) My tear! My tear! Com pack, my tear! (Lucy returns) Do my compliment to your mastair, und I shall make me mosh happy if I shall af de honeur to make me acquaintance mit him. My name is call Dr. Von Gostermans. I shall af de essence, und de cream, und de balsam, und de syrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earse, und de sea, und all dat vas subject under my command. I shall af de best recommendation for de honest Docteur dat vas possible. My Lordt und my Laty Fiprate vas my besten friend. I vas practice mit all de piggest family in de uniferse. Docteur Von Gostermans vas know efery poty; und efery poty vas know Docteur Von Gostermans. You tell him dat, my tear.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Tell him that? I cannot remember half of it! Are you, sir, acquainted with Lord Vibrate's family?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my tear. I vas make friendship mit dem more as many year.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: And do you know where they are?

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: To be sure he does. They are in this—

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (Aside to Master.) Hush! Silence your tongue! Dere is someting mystery. (Aloud.) If you shall make me introduce to your mastair, my tear, I shall tell him efery ting und more as dat, my tear. Vill you, my tear?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I will go and enquire.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Tank you, my tear. You are fery pretty girl, my tear: fery vitty pretty—Ah! You are so sly cunning little yipsey, my tear. Ah ah! [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE IV.
div3.stage: A chamber. MARIA in man's clothes with a letter in her hand and walking with anxiety. The Waiter enters and leaves the breakfast. She then reads.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: "Dear sister, The letter I now write is almost needless, for I shall leave Italy and follow it immediately; having at last obtained intelligence of your faithless lover. I am sorry to inform you that, in addition to your unpardonable wrongs, I have my own to vindicate. But I have threatened too long. You have heard of the Earl of Vibrate. He and his family are by this arrived in England; your betrayer accompanies them, and I am in close pursuit. PAUL DELAVAL."

In what will this end? Must they meet? Must they fight? Must one or both of them fall? Oh horror! Shall I be the cause of murder? And whose blood is to be spilled? That of the most generous of brothers, or of the man on whom my first and last affections have been fixed! Is there no safety; no means?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Why look here now, madam, you are letting the breakfast grow cold! You have been reading that letter again. I do believe I shall never get you to eat any more. Come now, pray do take some of this French roll; and I'll pour out the tea. Do! Pray do! Pray do!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I cannot eat, Lucy: I am eaten. Terror and despair are devouring me.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Dear! Dear! What will all this come to? Did not you promise me that, as soon as you had got safe to London in your disguise, you would be better?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Can it be? My kind, my gentle, my true hearted George!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: True hearted! No no, madam, he was never true hearted: or he could not so soon have changed, because his ill fortune changed to good. Every body knows true love never changes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: What have I done? How have I offended? His caresses, his protestations, his tender endearments! Is then the man in whom my soul was wrapt a vil—Oh!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I declare, madam, if you take on this way, you will break my heart as well as your own. Beside, you forget all the while what you put on this dress and came up to London for.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh no. It was if possible to prevent mischief! Murder!—They have never met. They do not know each other. But how shall I discover Sir George? Of whom shall I enquire?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: If you would but eat your breakfast, I do think I could put you in the way.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: By what means?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Will you eat your breakfast, then?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I cannot eat. Speak.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Why I have just been talking to an outlandish comical Doctor, that says he is acquainted with Lord Vibrate.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Indeed! Where is this Doctor?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: He is waiting without: for I knew you would wish to speak to him.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Shew him in immediately.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I'll tell him you are not well; which is but too true; though you must remember, madam, you are a man. So dry your eyes, forget your misfortunes, and, there, cock your hat, a that fashion, and try to swagger a little; or you will be found out. You stand so like a statue, and look so pitiful! Lord, that's not the way! If you are timorsome, and silent, and bashful, nobody on earth will take you for a youth of fortune and fashion.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (In revery.) If they should meet! Heavens! They must not.

div3.head: SCENE VI. Re-enter LUCY and DOCTOR.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: My master is not very well: he eats neither breakfast, dinner nor supper, and gets no sleep.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He noder eat, noder drink, noder sleep! Dat is pad! Fery pad! But dat it as noting at all, my tear. Let me do. You shall see presently py and py vat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Your servant, sir.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Sair, I vas your mosh oblishe fery omple sairfant, sair. My name is call Dr. Von Gostermans.
I shall af de best recommendation for de honest Docteur dat vas possible. I vas practice mit all de piggest family in de uniferse. Docteur Von Gostermans is know efery pody; und efery pody is know Dr. Von Gostermans. De pretty coquine yung frau tell me dat you not fery fell. You not eat, you not drink, you not sleep. Dat is pad! Fery pad! Bote dat is as noting at all. You tell me de diagnostic und de prognostic of all vat you vill ail; und I shall make you prescripe for de anodyne, oder de epipastic, oder de balsamic, oder de narcotic, oder de diaphoretic, oder de expectoratic, oder de restoratif, oder de emulsif, oder de incisif; vhich is efery ting so shveet und so delectable as all vat is possible.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Your pardon, sir, but I wish to see you on business of another nature.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ah! Someting of de prifate affair! Dat is coot. I shall be as better for dat as for de oder. I vas know de vorl. I vas know efery pody; und efery pody vas know me. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Perhaps then you happen to know Sir George Versatile?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, Der Teufel, sair! Ya, ya. Sair Shorge is my besten friend. Vhich it vas six month dat he vas succeed to his title und estate; und den I vas make acquaintance mit him: dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But he has been abroad since.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Ya, sair. Ven he vas poor, he vas fall in lofe mit fery pretty yung frau. Bote so soon as he vas pecome rish paronet dat vas anoder ting! So
his relation und his friend vas sent him to make de Gran tour.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And he was easily persuaded.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. He vas vat you call fery coot nature: he vas alvay comply.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Compliance with him is more than a weakness: I fear it is a vice.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: So he vas make acquaintance mit Lordt und mit Laty Fiprate: und den he vas tink no more of de pretty yung frau, pecause he vas fall in lofe mit anoder.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Sir! Another! What other?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Vat you shall ail, sair? You shange coleur.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: With whom has he fallen in love?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Mit de taughter of Lordt Fiprate.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: With Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair: mit Laty Shane—My cot, sair! vat you shall ail? You not make fall in lofe yourself mit Laty Shane?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: No, no—They are no doubt to be married.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Cot, sair! you so pale as deaths—My Cot, you shall faint!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Faint, indeed! (Aside) Bear up, madam. (Aloud) My master is too much of a man to faint. (Aside) I'll run for a glass of water. [Exit.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: The charming Lady▪ Jane—Where is she?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Lordt und my Laty Fiprate und my Laty Shane vas all in de house here.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: In this house?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And is Sir George here, too?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He is com und go alvay sometime efery tay.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Are they to be married?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Cot, sair! you af de ague fit.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Are they to be married?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Laty Fiprate vas mosh incline to Sair Shorge; und my Lordt vas sometime mosh incline too; und den he vas sometime not mosh incline; und den he vas doubt; und den he vas do me de honeur to consultate mit me.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And what is your advice?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Lordt Fiprate vas my besten friends, und I vas adfice dat he shall do all as vat he please: und Sair Shorge vas my besten friends too, und I vas adfice dat he shall do all as vat he please: und my Laty Fiprate vas petter as my besten friends, und den I vas more adfice dat she shall do all as vat she please.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But Lady Jane had another lover?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. Mr. Delafal vas make lofe mit her. He vas com from de East Indie, und he vas lofe her fery mosh; und she vas go mit de family to Italy, und my Laty Fiprate vas make acquaintance mit Sair Shorge, pecause he vas so mosh pleasant und coot humeur, und he say all as vat she say: vhich vas de vay to alvay make agréable.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Could you do me the favor to introduce me to Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. I shall do all as vat shall make agréable. Dat is my vay.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside to her mistress) Oh, madam, don't be terrified, but I declare I have spilled almost all the water!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Alarmed) What is the matter?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: He is come!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Who? Sir George?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: No: don't be frightened: Mr. Delaval, from abroad.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My brother! Heavens! Did he see you?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: No. I had a▪glimpse of him, and whisked away just as he stepped out of the postchaise.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Should he meet me in this disguise, what will he say?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Send away the Doctor, and let us lock ourselves up.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (To the Doctor) I must beg you will excuse me, sir; but it is necessary at present I should be alone. With your permission, I will see you again in the afternoon; and, in the mean time— (Gives money)

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, sair! I vas your mosh oblishe fery omple sairfant, sair. I shall make you mosh more fisit; und den you shall tell me de diagnostic und de prognostic of all vat you vill all.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Yes yes, another time.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und I shall af de essence, und de cream, und de balsam, und de syrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable, und de air, und de earse, und de sea, und all dat vas subject under my command.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: You have told us all that before.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Und I shall make you prescripe for de anodyne, oder de epipastic, oder de balsamic, oder de soporific, oder de narcotic, oder de diaphoretic, oder de expectoratic, oder de restoratif, oder de emulsif, oder de incisif, vhich is efery ting so shveet und delectable as all vat is possible.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside) Was ever any thing so provoking?—Pray, sir, make haste.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: You shall make remembrance of Dr. Von Gostermans. I am practice mit all de piggest family in de uniferse. Sair, I vas your mosh oblishe fery omple sairfant, sair. (The Doctor goes off talking, and Lucy locks the door while the scene changes.)

div3.head: SCENE IX. The hall of the hotel.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Is the portmanteau safe?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: And the trunks?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: All right.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Have you paid the postillions?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: MASTER.
sp.p: (To Delaval) This way if you please, sir. Jenkins!

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Coming, sir.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Shew the damask room. What will you please to have for breakfast, sir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: MAS.
sp.p: Bring tea, coffee, and new laid eggs.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: In a minute, sir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (To Williams) Observe the directions I gave you. Enquire, immediately, and find if the Vibrate family be in town?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I will be careful, sir.—Hay?— (To Delaval going)—Sir! Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Look! Here comes Lord Vibrate's secretary!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (To Thompson) Mr. Thompson!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Delaval? I am heartily glad to see you in England!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Thank you, my good friend. But how is this? Where is the family? Where is Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I thought that would be your question! They are all in this house.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I knew, when Lady Jane left Italy, your stay there would be short.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Ay, ay! The follies and frenzies of the madman are visible to all eyes, except his own.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I see you are dissatisfied.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Tortured, till my thoughts and temper are so changed that I am almost as odious to myself as the world is become hateful to me.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I own, you have some cause.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Would my injuries were all! But there are other and still deeper stabs. It is not yet ten months since I returned from India: my heart how light, my eve how cheerful, and my hand prompt at any commendable act. I could then be moved to joy, and sorrow, and every sympathising passion. Smiles and mock courtesy passed current on me, the word of man and woman was taken on trust, and I lived in the sunshine of an open unsuspecting soul. But I am now otherwise taught. I am changed. My better part is brutalized; and the wrongs that lie rankling here have stripped me of human affections, and made me almost savage.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: What can be said? Patience is the—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
Talk not of patience: I must act. I
may then perhaps enquire whether I have acted rightly? But I must first see Lady Jane, and Lord Vibrate.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Shall I inform his lordship of your arrival?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: By no means. Having injured, he may wish not to see me: and I would not afford him time to invent excuses, and avoid giving me a hearing. Though my wrongs must be endured, they shall be told.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I own, they are great.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Those that you know are heavy; yet, severe as the struggle would be, 'tis possible they might be hushed to rest: but there are others▪ which blood only can obliterate! which can only sleep in death! Such is the road I must travel. Not long since nature was jocund, the azure heavens were bright, and pleasure was in every path; but now darkness, fathomless gulphs, guilty terrors, and all the dreadful phantoms of meditated desolation, lie before me. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I.
div3.stage: LORD VIBRATE at a table with a quarto volume reading.

sp.speaker: LORD VIBRATE.
sp.p:
THE ancient sceptics doubted of every thing, affirmed nothing, and kept the judgment always in suspense: All things, said they, are equally indifferent, uncertain, and indeterminate. The mind is never to assent to any thing; that it may never be astonished, or disturbed, but enjoy
a perfect calm. (Rises with important wisdom in his looks) Such were the maxims of Pyrrho, and his disciples; those renowned sages of antiquity! Well! And such too have been my maxims, practically. All my life have I been wavering, uncertain, and indeterminate! A sagacious sceptic without knowing it; and as it were by instinct! It was but lately I discovered what a wise man I am! And yet it seems to me as if I were scarcely half wise enough, for I am told that I am to doubt of every thing which I find rather difficult. For example: that my wife Lady Vibrate is an extravagant rackety rantipole woman of fashion, can I doubt that? No. That she squanders my money, disturbs my peace, and contradicts for contradiction's sake, can I doubt that? No. Then have I not a daughter to marry, a law suit to begin, and a thousand perplexing affairs so that I do not know which way to turn? Why all this appears true to me: but the sceptics teach that appearances deceive, and that nothing is certain. I may be Lord Vibrate, or I may be the Grand Turk. These doctrines are prodigiously deep. (Considers) But I must think of something else just now. I have a thousand things to do, and know as little where to begin as where they will end. Ay! All is uncertainty! (Rings) Harry! Edward!

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: Did your lordship call?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Where are my servants? I want some of my plagues.

sp.speaker: JENK.
sp.p: They are ready at hand, my lord. Here is your lordship's secretary.

div3.head: SCENE III.
div3.stage: Enter MR. THOMPSON, and exit JENKINS.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What is the reason, Mr. Thompson, that nobody waits? Here am I, fretting myself to a mummy for the good of my family, while every body about me is as drowsy as the court of common council after dinner! Have they taken laudanum? Are they in a lethargy? Are they all dead?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: If they were, your lordship would have the goodness to raise them.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Don't you know how many people I have to see, and places I have to go to?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why, did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then how can you say you don't know?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Because I venture to presume, my lord, you do not know yourself.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I am distracted with doubts. Harry!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Did your lordship call?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Where are you all? What are you about? I think you have lived long enough with me to know my way.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord: we know it very well.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: If you are not more attentive, I'll discharge you every one.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Oh no: (Half aside) you will not do that.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What are you muttering, sirrah?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Only, my lord, that we know your way.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Order the coach at eleven.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No. Order it at one.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Come back! Order it in ten minutes, and remember I am not at home. Come back! Don't order it at all.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Must visitors be admitted?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Yes. No. I cannot tell. I will consider. Be within call. Thompson!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Step to that picture dealer. I will have the Guido. Yet—'tis a great sum! No—It is a master piece. I must have it. Why don't you go?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The picture is sold, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Sold? Gone? Have I lost it? This is always the way! I am for ever disappointed. Harry!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did you go with the message to the stable keeper, last night?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Let me know when he comes.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: He will come no more, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Come no more?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: He says you never know your own mind, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Insolent fellow!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Dr. Gosterman is below.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Admit him. Stay. I cannot see him yet. In half an hour. In ten minutes. By and by.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I must not waste my time in these trifles. I must attend to this law business. I wish I could determine. What am I to do, Thompson?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: In what, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The affair of the ejectment. If I once embroil myself in law, there will be no end; and if I do not the consequences are still worse.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Then they are bad indeed, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: 'Tis strange that I can come to no resolution, on this subject.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: (Aside.) Nor on any other.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I must decide this very day, or the time will be elapsed.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: A lawyer I should suppose, my lord, would give you the best advice.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: How? Are you mad, Thompson? A lawyer give good advice!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The present possessor has held the estate twenty years.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Not till tomorrow. I have time still to make my claim. How shall I act?—Shall I never leave this hotel?—Has the builder been here?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I can get nothing done. My whole life long I have been distracted with the multiplicity of my affairs.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: And so I am afraid, my lord, you always will be.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why so, sir?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Because your lordship undertakes so much, and does so little.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: So he has not been here?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Nor the lawyers?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Nor my steward?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Nor Sir George?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Where is Lady Vibrate? Where is Lady Jane? Are they all in their graves? Have none of them shewn signs of life yet?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Not one. Your lordship is the only person in the family who begin your miseries so soon in a morning.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The crosses and cares that prey upon me are enough to make any man on earth miserable.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord, but if you would care less both yourself and your servants would sleep the more. My lady cares for nothing; and she can sleep, when she is in bed, and sing and dance and laugh at your lordship's cares and fears, when she is up.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: She will drive me mad!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: (Going.) Ah! Here she is, as it were for the purpose.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Tell Harry to admit the Doctor—No. Not just yet. Yes. In five minutes. I don't know when. [Exit Thompson.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Upon my honor, my lord, you are the most insupportable person imaginable. You vociferate worse than the man who calls when my carriage stops the way. Is any body dying? Is the house on fire? Is the world at an end?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: By the life your ladyship leads, I should suppose it is pretty near.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You always give me such shocking head-achs of a morning.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You always give me such shocking heart-achs of an evening.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Did not I send to you last night, to request your lordship would not disturb me?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: It has been your ladyship's amusement to disturb me all your life.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Your lordship knows I love amusement.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I have not slept a wink since.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You had slept quite enough before. Pray how long are we to remain in this hotel? Your lordship should remember, it is degrading for a man of rank to doze away life, in the stile of a colonel reduced to half pay.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Your ladyship should remember, it is degrading for a woman of rank to riot away life, and reduce her creditors to live without pay.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Pshaw! That is the old story.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: But it is a very true story. It is a great misfortune that persons so opposite should pair.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
A terrible one indeed. I am all gaiety and good humour: you are all turmoil and lamentation. I sing, laugh, and welcome pleasure
wherever I find it: you take your lantern to look for misery, which the sun itself cannot discover.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I am overwhelmed by crosses and vexations; and you participate in none of them.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No. Heaven be praised!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Will you attend to me, my lady, for half an hour?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Mercy! Attend to you for half an hour! You, my lord, may think proper to be as miserable as Job: but I am not Job's wife.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I insist, Lady Vibrate, on a serious answer. How ought I to act? What should I do, in this law affair?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I cannot tell what you ought to do: but I know what you will do.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Do you? What?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The recovery of this property would enable me to give my daughter a portion suitable to her rank. If it is lost, she will be almost destitute of fortune.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You should have thought of that before, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Before? Why I have thought of nothing else for years. I have asked every body's advice.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And followed nobody's.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: It shall be so. The ejectment shall be served: proceedings shall commence.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I say, they shall. I am determined.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I know you, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You know! I say they shall, if it be only to prove that you know nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! A pleasant motive! But even that will not be strong enough.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: But it will, my lady.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But it won't, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I say it will, my lady.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I say it won't, my lord.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Coot morgen, to my coot lordt und my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, Doctor, stop my lady's tongue.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, Doctor, give my lord a quieting draught.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I shall do efery ting as vat you desire, my coot lordt und my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Can nothing silence you, Lady Vibrate? Shall I never have a quiet hearing? I want to talk with you and the Doctor on a thousand things.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Yes; you wish to have all the talk to yourself.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: On the marriage of our daughter.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart. A marriage at least begins with music, feasting, and dancing, So say on.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I am not yet determined in favor of Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But I am. (While they speak, the Doctor gesticulates in favor of each.)

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr Delaval is an unobjectionable gentleman; and he was the first suitor.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sir George can sing; Sir George can dance; Sir George has air, grace, fashion, and fortune.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Pshaw! His best qualities are prudence, and attention to his own concerns. Ask the Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He has fery mosh prudence, my coot lordt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha! I vow, Sir George is the most airy, thoughtless, pleasant person living: except myself.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya; Sair Shorge is fery mosh pleasant: und my latyship is fery mosh more pleasant.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Absurd. His humour is calm, cold, and serious.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Fery serious, inteet.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Whimsical, animated, delightful.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Fery animate, fery telightful, upon my vordt.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I never met a more discreet sensible man in my life.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: True: for he thinks of nothing but his pleasures.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: His affairs, you mean.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I tell you, my lord, he is exactly what I wish: the very soul of levity, whim, and laughter.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I tell you, my lady, he is exactly like myself: prudent, and full of sage hesitation. He considers before he acts. Does he not, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yust as vat you say, my coot lordt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: He never considers at all. Does he, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yust as vat you say, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: How so? We cannot both be right.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
You shall please to make me parton, my coot lordt. Sair Shorge vas all as vat you say;
und all as vat my coot laty say. Mit my laty, he vas merry: mit my lordt, he vas sad. Mit my laty, he vas laugh, und vas sing, und vas tance: und he vas make melancholy, und misery, und vas do all dat shall make agréable mit my lordt.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is he so variable?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, he vas fery mosh comply: fery mosh coot humeur. He vas alvay make agréable. Bote vas my lordtship und my latyship know dat Mr. Delafal vas com from Italy?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Come where? To England?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He vas in de house below. I vas see und speak mit his falet.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: In this hotel?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: He vas yust arrife, und vas demandt dat he shall see my lordtship; oder my latyship.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I am very sorry he is here. He is a dun of the most disagreeable kind, and shall not see me; and I hope, my lord, you will no longer permit his addresses to Lady Jane. My word is given to Sir George. Come with me, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord, if I intrude with too little ceremony. Something I hope will be allowed to a mind much disturbed, and a heart deeply wounded and impatient to ease its pangs.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Which way deeply wounded, Mr. Delaval?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Can your lordship ask? Was it not with your permission I paid my addresses to Lady Jane? And was the ardour of my affection or the extent of my hopes unknown?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why, I did permit, and I did not. I had my doubts.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: My visits were daily, their purpose was declared, and I should imagine I spoke more respectfully to say that you permitted than that you connived at them.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: True: but still I had my doubts.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Those doubts have stung me to the soul; and I could wish you had expressed them more decidedly.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Impossible! Doubts here, doubts there, doubts every where. No rational man can be decided, on any point whatever. My doubts are my continual plagues: my whole life is consumed by them,

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: It appears, my lord, you have conquered them on one subject.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay indeed! I wish to heaven I had! What subject is that?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You have affianced your daughter to Sir George Versatile.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Humph!—Yes; and no. I have; and I have not. I cannot determine. Sir George is a prudent man, his estate is large, and the Versatiles are an ancient race. But your family is ancient, you are prudent, and the wealth left by your uncle is at least equal. What can I say? What can I do? I don't know which to take nor which to refuse. I am everlastingly in these difficulties. I am harassed night and day by them: they are the night mare, they sit upon my bosom, oppress me, suffocate me. I cannot act. I cannot move.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
This, my lord, may be an apology to yourself, but the consequence to me is misery. Your daughter lived in my heart: with her I had promised
myself ages of happiness; and had cherished a passion, impatient perhaps, but, ardent and pure as her own thoughts. This passion your conduct authorized. My fortune, my life, my soul, were devoted to her. Mine was no light or wanton dalliance; nor did I expect a light and wanton conduct from the noble family of which your lordship is the head.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What do you mean, Mr. Delaval? I told you I was undecided; and so I am still. My lady, you know, was never much your friend. Sir George is her favourite.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: And is Lady Jane equally changeable?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I don't know. She is my daughter; and, judging by myself, I should suppose she is perplexed, and doubtful. She never, I believe, declared in your favour?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Not expressly, my lord. She referred me to time and you. 'Tis true I flattered myself her affections were wholly mine. Should she prefer Sir George, or any other man, be my feelings what they will, I then am silenced. My heart could not be satisfied with cold compliance. Oh no! 'Tis of a different stamp. I am told she is not at home. I hope however she will not have the cruelty to deny me a last interview: till when I take my leave. Only suffer me to remark that, had you discovered in me any secret vice, any defects dangerous to the happiness of the woman I adore, you then were justified in your present conduct. But, if you have no such accusation to prefer, I must do my feelings the violence to declare I cannot but think it highly unworthy of a man of honor. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval—Insolent!—Highly unworthy of a man of honor?—I will challenge him.—He shall find whether I am a man of honor, or no. I will challenge him. Harry!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Run. Tell that Mr. Delaval—Hold—Yes, fly! Tell him—Stay. Get me pen ink and paper—I will teach him to insult—No. I will not do him the honor to write. Order him back.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Order who, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He shall give me satisfaction. In that at least I am determined. He shall give—And yet what is satisfaction? Is it to be run through the body? Shot through the head? A man may then indeed be said to be satisfied—I had forgotten my doubts on duelling—Tell my lady I wish to speak to her. No—

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: She is here, my lord. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE XI. Enter LADY VIBRATE and the DOCTOR.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: What is the matter, my lord? You seem to be even in a worse humour than usual!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval has treated me disrespectfully!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Have not I a thousand times told you he is a disagreeable impertinent person?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why, God forgive me, but I really find myself of your ladyship's opinion! 'Tis a thing I believe that never happened before!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
And a thing I believe that will never
happen again! I hope, my lord, you are now determined in favor of Sir George?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Positively. Finally. I pledge my honor.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You hear, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my coot laty; I vas hear.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I say, I pledge my honor. I authorise you, my lady, to deliver that message to the baronet: and, that I may not have time to begin to doubt, I will instantly be gone. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: This is fortunate!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, fery mosh fortunate! fery mosh!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Had Mr. Delaval married my daughter, we should have had a continual sermon on reason, common sense, and good order! And these and such like antediluvian notions must have been introduced to our family.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah, dat shall be pad! fery pad inteet, my coot laty!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Now that Sir George is the man, the danger is over.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is creat plessing!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But what think you are my daughter's thoughts? I fear she has a kind of esteem for Delaval. He was her first lover.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya; she vas fery mosh esteem Mr. Delafal, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But I observe she listens with great pleasure to the gay prattle of Sir George.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh! fery creat inteet, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: We must second the rising passion: for we must get rid of that solemn sir.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yust as vat you say, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Go to her, Doctor; convince her how intolerable it will be to have a husband whom she cannot quarrel with, nor reproach. Paint in the most lively colours the stupid life she must lead, with so reasonable a man.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I shall do efery ting as vat shall make agréable, my coot laty. Dat is my vay. My laty, I vas your mosh oblishe fery omple sairfant, my laty. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I. The hall of the hotel. WILLIAMS and HARRY. LUCY speaking to the master of the hotel.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: ALL you say is very true, Mr. Harry. Our masters suppose we have neither sense nor feeling; yet exact every thing that requires the five senses in perfection. They expect we should know their meaning before they open their lips; yet won't allow we have common understanding.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: More shame for 'em. I warrant for all that we can game, run in debt, get in drink, and be as proud and domineering as they for their lives.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, yes: let them but change places and they would soon find we could rise to their vices, and they could sink to ours, with all the ease imaginable.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: They have no such notion though, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: That is their vanity, Mr. Harry. I have lived with Mr. Delaval ever since he returned from India; and, though he is a good— (Sees Lucy) Hay! Surely—It must be her! Do you know that young woman, Mr. Harry?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: No: but I have heard a strange story about her.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Ay!—It is!—What?—I am sure it is Lucy!—What strange story have you heard?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Why that she came here late last night with a young gentleman, now above, pretending to be his waiting maid.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: With a gentleman!— (Aside) Oh the jilt! Waiting maid to a man? I never heard of such a thing!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: Nor any body else.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aside) The deceitful hussey!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: (Hears a bell) That's my lord's bell. I told you, he is never easy. I must go.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aside) I am glad of it—By all means, Mr. Harry. Good-day— [Exit Harry.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Run away with a gentleman! Oh!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Coming forward) I declare, there is Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aside) What a fool was I to believe she loved me!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside) How my heart beats! Dear, dear! I could wish to speak to him—but then if any harm should come of it?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aside) She shall not escape me!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside) I should like to ask him how he does—But I must not betray my dear lady. (Going)

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Placing himself in her way) I beg pardon, ma'am.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside) Does not he know me?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I thought I had seen you before; but I find I am mistaken!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside) What does he mean?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: You are very like a young woman I once knew.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Aside) How angry he looks!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: But she was a modest pretty behaved person; and not an arrant jilt.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Who is a jilt, Mr. Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: One Lucy Langford, that I courted and promised to marry: but I know better, now.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: You do, Mr. Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I do, madam.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: It is very well, Mr. Williams! It is very well! Pray let me go about my business!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Oh, to be sure! I have no right to stop you.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: You have no right to speak to me as you do, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: No, no; ha, ha, ha! I dare say, I have not.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Her passions rising) No, you have not; and so I beg you will let me pass. My mistress—I mean—

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Ay, ay! You mean, your master.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Do I, sir? Well! Since you please to think so—so be it.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: All the servants know it is a man! Would you deny it?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p:
I deny nothing, Mr. Williams; and, if
you are minded to make this an excuse for being as treacherous as the rest of your sex, (Keeping down her sobs) you are very welcome, Mr. Williams—I shall neither die—nor cry, at parting.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I dare say not. The young gentleman above stairs will comfort you.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Bursts into tears) It is a base false story. I have no young gentleman above stairs, nor below stairs neither, to comfort me! and you ought to know me better.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Did you or did you not come here late last night?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: With a young gentleman?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: No. Yes. Don't ask me such questions.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: No! You are ashamed to answer them.

div3.head: SCENE III. MARIA from the staircase.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Calls) Lucy!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Ma'am! Sir! Coming, sir!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: There! There! I will see what sort of a spark it is, however.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Struggling) Be quiet, then! Keep away! You shan't!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Descending) What is the matter? Who is molesting you?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (To Maria) Go back, sir! Go back!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I will see, I am determined!

div3.head: SCENE IV. DELAVAL from a room door.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Williams!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I tell you, I will. (Looking at Maria) Hay! Bless me!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Why, Lucy! Mr. Williams!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: My young lady, as I live!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Why do not you answer, Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Coming, sir!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Mercy! It is my brother's voice! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Hide your face with your handkerchief, ma'am. Pull down your hat.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Pray do not betray me, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: If you do, I will never speak to you as long as I have breath to draw.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: How betray?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Don't say you know us. Mind! Not for the world!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Maria and Lucy up the staircase.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: What is it you are about, Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Nothing, sir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: What do you mean by nothing? Whom were you wrangling with?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Me, sir? Wrangling, sir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Why are you so confused?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why, sir, I—I committed a small mistake. I was asking—asking after a gentleman that that that proved not to be a gentleman—that is—not not the gentleman that I supposed.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Why did you not come back with your message?—Have you learnt the address of Sir George?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Yes, sir: he lives in Upper Grosvenorstreet; his name on the door.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
Well, be in the way.—The day shall not pass before I see him. My own wrongs I could forgive. He it seems is preferred; and perhaps
I have no right to complain: But for his injuries to my sister he shall render me a dear account.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: What can be the reason of Miss Delaval's disguise?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (Peeping from the top of the stairs) Hst! Hst! Mr. Williams!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Is it you?—Oh! now I shall know.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Really, daughter, I cannot understand you.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No wonder, madam; for I do not half understand myself.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Is it possible you can hesitate? The good humour and complaisance of Sir George might captivate any woman.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: They are very engaging: but they are dangerous.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: His character is too pliant. If others are merry, so is he: if they are sad, he is the same. Their joys and sorrows play upon his countenance: but, though they may slightly graze, they do not penetrate his heart. Even while he relieves, he scarcely feels them.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Pshaw! He is a delightful man.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I grant he does his utmost. But it is a folly to be the slave even of an endeavour to please.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Upon my honor, you are a whimsical young lady! Afraid of marrying
a man because of his assiduous endeavours to please! As if that were a husband's failing! You can prefer no such accusation against Mr. Delaval.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I own he is of a very different character. Firm and inflexible, he imagines he makes virtue his rule, and reason his guide.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Firm indeed? No, no: ferocious, obstinate, perverse. Sir George tries to be agreeable, and is successful: Mr. Delaval has no fear of offending, and does not miss his aim.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Heaven help us! We all have faults and follies enough.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval never was approved by me; and this morning he has insulted your father.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Insulted! How do you mean, madam? Mr. Delaval is abroad! Has he written?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No. He is here.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Here! And has he not thought proper to let me know of his arrival?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No, no. The haughty gentleman has only thought proper to reproach Lord Vibrate for admitting the pretensions of Sir George. He is too proud to endure a competitor.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Indeed! Such pride is the very way to insure his competitor success. Insulted my father!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I will leave you to judge how deeply when I tell you that, fluctuating and undecided as Lord Vibrate always is, he was so offended that he pledged his honor in favor of Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Insult my father, and not deign to let me know of his arrival!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I hope, when Sir George comes, you will admit him.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Certainly, madam; certainly.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And that Mr. Delaval will be denied.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: It seems I need give myself no concern about that: the gentleman will not even take the trouble to send up his name.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I am glad you feel it properly.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Pardon me, madam. I will not condescend to feel it, in the least. It shall not affect me; no not for a moment. I had indeed conceived a very different opinion of Mr. Delaval. I am glad I have discovered my error, before it is too late. I could not have believed it possible! But it shall not disturb me. It shall give me no uneasiness. I will keep myself perfectly cool, and unconcerned, and—ungenerous, unfeeling man!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: She is delightfully piqued, and Sir George will succeed!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Without) Are the ladies above?

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: (Without) Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I hear him! The very sound of his voice inspires mirth.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Lady!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I am infinitely glad to see you, Sir George! You are come at a lucky moment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is then my fate decided?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: It is! It is!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Happy tidings!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But first tell me—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Any thing! Every thing! Speak!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Are you not of my opinion?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To be sure I am! What is it?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: That pleasure is the business of life.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, beyond all doubt!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: That inspecting accounts—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is vulgar drudgery!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And looking after our affairs—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A vile loss of time!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: That care in the face denotes—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The owner a fool!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And that sorrow is a very ridiculous thing!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Fit only to excite laughter!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Why then, Sir George, I am your friend.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ten thousand thousand thanks! But, what says my lord?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Would you believe it? He consents, has pledged his honor, and sent the message by me.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Rapture! Enchantment!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Yes. The reign of pleasure is about to begin!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Light, free, and fantastic; dancing an eternal round!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No domestic troubles!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No grave looks!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No serious thoughts!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: We will never think at all!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No cares, no frowns!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: None, none, by heavens, none! It shall be spring and sunshine all the year!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Then our appearance in public!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Splendid! Dazzling!—Driving to the opera!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Dressing for Ranelagh!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A phaeton to-day!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: A curricle to-morrow!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Dash over the downs of Piccadilly, descend the heights of St. James's, make the tour of Pall-mall, coast Whitehall—

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Back again to Bond-street—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Scour the squares, thunder at the doors!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: How do you do? How do you do? How do you do?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And away we rattle, till stone walls are but gliding shadows, and the whole world a Galanty show.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You are a charming man, Sir George! and Lady Jane is yours.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My dear lady, your words inspire me! I am all air, spirit, soul! I tread the milky way, and step upon the stars!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: But you must not, before the marriage, talk thus to Lord Vibrate. Silly man! He and you will never agree.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh yes, but we shall. I—I—I like his humour!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Do you?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Prodigiously! Whenever I am in his company, I am as grave as Good Friday.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He is full of sage reflection. So am I. Doubtful of every thing. So am I. Anxious for the present, provident for the future. So am I. Overflowing with prudential maxims; sententious, sentimental, and solemn. So am I.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You sentimental!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: As grace before meat, in the mouth of an alderman.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You solemn!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: As the black patch on a judge's wig.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I must tell you, Sir George, I hate sentiment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! So do I!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Solemnity is all a farce.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And those that act it buffoons. I know it!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I love mirth, pleasantry—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Humour, whim, wit, feasting, revelry, shout, song, dance, and joke. So do I! So do I! So do I!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: The very mention of duties and cares makes me splenetic.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Curse catch duties! I hate them! Give me life, the wide world, the fair sun, and the free air!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I say, give me midnight, the rattling of chariot wheels, and the lighted flambeau!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay! A rout! A crash of coaches! A lane of footmen! A blazing stair-case! A squeeze through the anti-chamber! Card tables! Wax lights! Patent lamps! Bath stoves and suffocation! Oh lord! Oh lord!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Exquisite! You are a delightful man!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Am I?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You enter perfectly into all my ideas!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Do I?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: And describe them even better than I myself can.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, my dear lady!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Yes, you do.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
But then, ha, ha, ha! That you
should be able to fall in with my lord's absurdities so!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nothing more easy. I have one infallible rule to please all tempers. I learnt it of our friend the Doctor.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sure! What is that?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I prove that every body is always in the right.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Prove my husband to be in the right! Do if you can.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My lord loves to be restless, and doubtful, and distressed: he delights in teasing and tormenting himself; and why should I interrupt his pleasures?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Very true.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I fail in with his humour. I shew him how rational it is, afford him new arguments for discontent, and encourage him to be miserable.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh you malicious divle!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My dear lady, you mistake. I do it from pure compassion. It makes him happy. Every child delights in the squeaking of its own trumpet; and shall I have the cruelty to break the toy? A well bred person is cautious never to contradict. It is become a very essential requisite to say Ay, and No, in the most complying manner possible.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ah, Sir George, you are one of the dear inimitable few.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Only a copy of your charming self.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You and I must totally reform our stupid family. Amusement shall be our perpetual occupation.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Day and night.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: We will commence with your marriage. It shall be splendid!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A feast, a concert, a ball! The whole town shall ring with it!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I hate a private wedding. A small select party is my aversion.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, nothing is so insipid! Pleasure cannot be calm.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I wish to be seen, and heard—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And talked of, and paragraphed, and praised, and blamed, and admired, and envied, and laughed at, and imitated!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I live but in a crowd.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Give me hurry, noise, embarrassment—

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Confusion, disorder—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Tumult, tempest, uproar, elbowing, squeezing, pressing, pushing, squeaking, squalling, fainting!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Exquisite! Transporting!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You remember I receive masks this evening?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Can I forget?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You will be there?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: There? Ay! Though I should come in my coffin.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! An excellent idea! I never yet saw a mask in the character of a Memento mori.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ah! Turn about, and you will see a Memento mori without a mask!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: (Without) I cannot tell. I will consider, and send an answer.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
Here he comes, to interrupt our delightful dreams: a very antidote to mirth and
pleasure. He will give you a full dose of the dismals. But you must stay and speak to him. Remember, his honor is pledged: insist upon that. I pity but cannot relieve you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I have been too sudden. I ought not to have pledged my honor. This is the consequence of hasty determination: of not doubting before we decide. Shall I never correct myself of that fault? (Sees Sir George. They look full at each other till Sir George catches the same dismal kind of countenance) Ah, Sir George! Here am I, brim full of anxiety and turmoil!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Alas! Man was born to trouble.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Perplexed on every side; thwarted in every plan: no domestic comfort, no friend to grieve with me, no creature to share my miseries.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Melancholy case!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: One crossing me, another blaming me, and my wife driving me mad!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Distressing situation!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: My cares laughed at, my vigilance mocked, my sufferings insulted! And why? Because I am cautious! because I doubt! because I am provident! What is man without money?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A fountain without water.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: A clock without a dial.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Warming and becoming rapid as he proceeds) What is it that buys respect, and honor, and power, and privilege, and houses, and lands, and wit, and beauty, and learning, and lords, and commons, and—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why money!—Then the manners of this dissipated age!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: They are truly shocking! They, they, they are absurd, ridiculous, odious, abominable.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: And to what do they lead?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To every thing that is horrid! To loss of peace, loss of property, loss of principle, loss of respect, bankruptcy, ruin, contempt, disease, and death!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: (Aside) Yes, yes: he's the man! I do not think I repent—Heaven be praised, Sir George, you are a man of understanding; an economist. You will regulate your family and affairs to my heart's content.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! it shall be my study! my daily practice! my duty! my delight!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You make me happy—and yet I cannot but wonder, being so rational a man, how you and my lady should agree so well.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Dear, my lord, why so? Women are the most manageable good creatures upon earth.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Women good?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Indubitably: when they are pleased.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: So they say is the devil.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The sweet angels deserve to be humoured. Their smiles are so enchanting! And, should they frown, who can be angry when we know the dear wayward syrens will only look the more bewitching, as soon as they are out of their pouts? It is so delightful to see the Sun breaking from behind a cloud.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Pshaw! When a woman begins to grow old—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Hush! The Sun—The Sun never
grows old. I grant you that formerly there used to be old women: but there are none now!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then you think me a fool for being wretched at my wife's thoughtlessness, caprice, and impertinence?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, I don't. Every body tells us that wives were born to be the plague of their husbands.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: And mine is the greatest of plagues!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What is a wife's duty? To obey her lord and master. 'Tis her marriage promise, and the law binds her to it. She is the minister of his pleasures, the handmaid of his wants, his goods, his chattels, his vendible property.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay: we find the husband may take the wife to market in a halter.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: In which I should hope he would afterward hang himself!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: My lady thinks of nothing but revelling, and racketing, and turning the world upside down!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis a great pity.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Her tongue is my torment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: The perpetual motion! It never ceases!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then how can you like her company?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: She is not my wife.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No, or you would not be such good friends. Did she say any thing concerning the marriage?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, yes. She delivered your lordship's kind message.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, that I had pledged my honor?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Irrevocably.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I was very rash. Hasty resolutions bring long repentance—She insists that the nuptials shall be public!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Does she, indeed?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: For my part, I hate any display of vanity.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It is extremely ridiculous! What would our ostentation, pomp, and magnificence be, but advertising ourselves to the world as fools and coxcombs?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is that a rational use of money?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Should it not be applied to relieve the aged, comfort the poor, succour the distressed—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Reward merit, encourage industry, and promote the public good?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Promote a farce!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Very true: the public good is a farce!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The true use of money is to defend our rights—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Revenge our wrongs, purchase for the present, provide for the future, secure power, buy friends, bid defiance to enemies, and lead the world in a string!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay! Now you talk sense. So, if I should consent, the wedding shall be private.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Calm: tranquil.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No feasting.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No dancing: no music: no pantomime pleasures: but all silent, serene, pure, and undisturbed.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: We will just invite a select party.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A chosen few.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: None but our real and sincere friends.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And then we shall be sure the house will hold them.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: My lord, the builder desires to know if you will see him?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I. am coming. I will be with him in five minutes.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: He says, he can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Then let him go. I will be with him presently.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: The lawyers have sent word they are waiting for your lordship, at Counsellor Demur's chambers.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Very well. There let them wait. The law is slow, and every man ought to be slow who is going to law. Come with me, Sir George. I have some papers to consult you upon.

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: The tradespeople too are below.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Thus it is! I am eternally besieged! I never have a moment to myself!

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: This is the tenth time they have been here, by your lordship's own appointment.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: HAR.
sp.p: They are become quite surly. They all abuse me; and some of them don't spare your lordship.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Do you hear, Sir George?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh shocking! Your tradespeople are a sad unreasonable set. You cannot convince them that, if we were to keep our appointments, be punctual in our payments, and know what we do want and what we do not, we should no longer be persons of fashion.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p:
I am just come from the lawyers, my lord. The courts are sitting, their clients waiting,
and, if your lordship do not go immediately, they will be gone.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Very true; and this last opportunity of serving an ejectment will be lost. I have a thousand things to attend to. Would you be kind enough, Sir George, to go and—Hold—No—I don't know what to do! The estate is valuable: but law is damnable. I may lose the cause: it may cost even more than it is worth. Writs of error! Brought into chancery! Carried up to the Lords!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Then the stupidity of juries, the fictions of law, the chicanery of lawyers, their tricking, twisting, turning, lying, wrangling, browbeating, cajoling!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Their frauds, collusions, perjuries, robberies!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ay! Detinue, replevin, plea, imparlance, replication, rejoinder, rebutter, surrejoinder, surrebutter, demurrer—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Take breath! We ought both to demur: for it is the devil's dance, and both Plaintiff and Defendant are obliged to pay the piper.

div3.head: SCENE I. The apartments of LORD VIBRATE.
div3.stage: LADY JANE, her WOMAN, the DOCTOR, and FOOTMAN.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: TELL the young gentleman I wait his pleasure. (Exit Footman.) It is very singular! Men, I believe, do not often travel attended by waiting maids!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is de mystery, my Laty Shane.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What can he want to say to me?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is de more mystery, my Laty Shane. He vas fery mosh young, und fery mosh handsome, und he vas fery mosh make fall in lofe mit you, my Laty Shane.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Nonsense!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Laty Shane vas so full of de beauty dat you vas make sharm efery pody, my Laty Shane! Und as your name vas make mention, my Laty Shane, he vas all so pale as deaths!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside to her woman.) You are sure, you say, Mr. Delaval made enquiries; and sent up his name?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane.) Law, my lady! Could you think he would not? I saw him before ten o'clock; just as you sent me where I was kept so long: and, goodness! Had you beheld what a taking he was in! I warrant you, my lady, he asked a hundred and a hundred questions in a breath; and all about you!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Well, go now where I desired you.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Yes, my lady. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE II. Footman returns introducing MARIA. Salute.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside) Why do I tremble thus?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (To Doctor) What a charming countenance!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Oh, fery mosh sharming!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: How prepossessing his appearance!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya: he vas fery mosh possess.

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: Sir George has sent this domino and mask, to know if they meet your ladyship's approbation.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Italian refinement, copied after some Venetian Cicisbeo. Put them down.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside. Regarding the domino and mask.) Here his presents, and here his affections are now directed! How shall I support the scene?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: You wish, sir, to speak to me.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Faltering) Embarrassed by the—liberty—I have taken—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Let me request you to wave all apology, and tell me which way I can oblige or serve you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You are acquainted with Sir George—I—you—Pray pardon me. I am overcome. My spirits are—so agitated—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Eagerly reaching a chair.) Sit down, sir. You are unwell! Bless me! Doctor!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane significantly.) I vas tell my Laty Shane vat it vas—Here, sair, you shmell mit dat elixir; und I shall make your neck bandt tie loose, und— (Going to loosen her neckcloth.)

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Alarmed and putting him away.) Pray forbear!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (Aside. Imitating the heaving of the bosom.) Ah ha! Der Teufel! He vas a vomans!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Are you better?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: A moment's air. (Goes to the window.)

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: (Aside) Dat vas de someting mystery!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane.) If you would indulge me a few minutes in private?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: By all means—Doctor— (Whispers.)

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, ya, my Laty Shane, I vas unterstandt; und I vas do efery ting as vat shall make agréable. Dat is my vay—Sair, I vas your mosh oblishe fery omple sairfant, sair. I vas unterstandt. My Laty Shane, I vas your mosh oblishe fery omple sairfant, my Laty Shane— (Aside) Ah ha! [Exit.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Take courage, sir.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am unequal to the task. This disguise sits ill upon me.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What disguise?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am not what I seem. I—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am a woman.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Distressed—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: By poverty?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh no. I come to claim your counsel.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: To prevent mischief. The shedding of blood.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: The shedding of blood?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Without.) I will be with you again presently, my lady.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p:
Mercy! It is Sir George! What shall I do? He must not see me! This way— (Hurries on the domino and mask.) Aid me, dear lady, to
conceal myself; and excuse conduct which I cannot now explain.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Depend upon me, madam. (Aside) This is as unaccountable as it is alarming!

div3.head: SCENE IV. MARIA in the back ground. SIR GEORGE introduced by a Footman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I come, my charming Lady Jane, flying and full of business, to consult you on a thousand important affairs!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Surely! What are they?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Upon my soul, I don't know!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: They have every one slipped my memory.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Miraculous!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Whenever I have the inexpressible pleasure of enjoying your smiles, I can think of nothing else.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside) Perjured man!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: My smiles! Ha, ha, ha! What if I should happen to frown?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Impossible! No lowering clouds of discontent dare ever shade the heavenly brightness of your brow.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Very prettily said, upon my word. Where did you learn it?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: From you! 'Tis pure inspiration, and you are my muse.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No, no; 'tis a flight beyond me. I love plain prose.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
So do I! A mere common place matter of fact man▪ I! The weather, the time of the
