day, the history of where I dined last, the names and titles of the company, the dishes brought to table, the health, sickness, deaths, births and marriages of my acquaintance, and such like toothpick topics for me! I am as literal in my narratives as any town-crier; and repeat them as often.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Yet I should wish to talk a little common sense.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! So should I! I assure you, I am for pros and cons and whys and wherefores. Your Aristotles, and Platos, and Senecas, and Catos are my delight! I honor their precepts, venerate their cogitations, and adore the length of their beards! which luckily reminds me of the masquerade. Is my domino to your taste?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Ancient sages, dominos, and taste.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Did you not notice the colour?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Oh! The taste of a domino is in its colour?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why, no: but there may be meaning.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mine is saffron.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Cruel question! Hymen and his robe.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Oh oh!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside) She is pleased with his perfidy.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: A very significant riddle truly!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Advancing) Are you so soon to be married, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Bless me, Lady Jane! What frolicksome gentleman is this? In masquerade so early, and my domino!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Permit me once more to ask, if you are soon to be married?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Your question, sir, is improperly addressed. Put it, if you please, to that lady.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside to Sir George) Is that the lady to whom the question ought to be put?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) What does he mean?—Will you indulge me, sir, by taking off that mask?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis mine; and I am induced to claim it, from the great curiosity I have to see your face.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Do you not adore this lady?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) An odd question!—More than language can express!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh, falsehood!—Then I put myself under her protection.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You know guardian angels when you see them. Pray, however, let us become acquainted.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Twould gratify me. I should like you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I certainly should. There is something of pathos and music in your voice, which, which—I never heard but one to equal it.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And whose voice was that?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh, that—that was a voice so ingenuous, so affectionate, so fascinating!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But whose voice was it?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside) What does this mean?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Tell me, and you shall see my face.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside) Astonishing!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I must not—I dare not—I shall never hear it more!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Aside) My feelings so overpower me I shall betray myself. (To Lady Jane) Permit me to retire.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: You have alarmed and strangely moved me! I hope you will return?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh yes; and most happy to have your permission.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why do they whisper? (To Maria going) Will you not let me know who you are?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Because—I am one you do not love.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: One I do not love!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside) This is incomprehensible!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane) Oh, madam!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What more is the matter?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: For your life, do not mention the names of either of these gentlemen to the other!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What gentlemen?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: He is coming! They do not personally know each other. If they should, there would be murder! I dare not stay. For the love of God beware! [Exit masked as Delaval enters.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Calling) Harkye, sir, come back! My domino! I shall want it in an hour or so—Who have we here?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (With much agitation of manner) Your ladyship's very humble servant.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p:
Oh! How do you do? How do you do? (Aside) Who can that lady be? She knows them both, it seems; and knows their rivalship!
Her terror is contagious! Is their hatred so deadly? I shall certainly betray them to each other.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) What a strange behaviour she puts on! Does she affect to overlook me? (Observing Sir George) Who is this?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Are you just arrived?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: This very morning: sooner I fear than—than—was desired.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Do you think so? (To Sir George) Why don't you go to Lady Vibrate? She is waiting.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis the fate of forty.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To wait. (Aside. Eyeing Delaval) Who can this spark be, that she wants me gone?—Pray what is the name of the youth that has made so free with my domino and mask?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I really don't know.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Don't know?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I can't answer questions at present. I am flurried; out of humour.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I fear at my intrusion?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I wish you had come at another time.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I expected my visit would be unwelcome: let me request, however, to say a few words.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Well, well; another time, I tell you: when I am alone.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh ho!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: They were meant for your private ear.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) Were they so?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) By her confusion and his manner, I suspect this to be the base betrayer of my sister's peace: the man whose bare image makes my heart sicken, and my blood recoil.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside) Will they neither of them go?—Why do you loiter here, Sir Ge— (Coughs)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I must stay till the gentleman brings back my domino and mask, you know. (Aside) I'll not leave them.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) I am persuaded it is he—Excuse me, sir: would you indulge me with the favour of your name?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My name, sir! My name is—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside to Sir George) Hush! Don't tell it!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (To Lady Jane) Why not?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I insist upon it!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay, then—My name, sir, is a very pretty name. Pray what is yours?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) Yes, yes, it must be he—Have you any reason to be ashamed of it?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir! Did you please to speak? Upon my honor, you are a very polite pleasant person.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) If I should be mistaken—I acknowledge, sir, there is but one man, whose name I do but whose person I do not know, to whom that question would not have been rude in the extreme. Should you not be that man, I ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Should I not! Sir, that I may be sure I am not, allow me to ask his name?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: His name is—

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Screams and sinks on the chair) Oh!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Good Heavens!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What has happened?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Are you ill?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is it cramp, or spasm?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Surely you have not broken a blood vessel?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Shall I run for a physician?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Instantly.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I fly! Yet I must not leave you!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No delay, if you value my life.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Your life! I will go!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Detaining him) No, no.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I fly! I fly! [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE VI. Enter LADY JANE'S woman.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Dear! my lady, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Lead me directly to my own room.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Shall I carry you?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No: only give me your arm, and come with me. I want to talk to you. I wish to hear what you have to say. (Aside to her woman) When Sir George comes back, tell him I am partly recovered, but must not be disturbed. It is my positive order.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) What does she whisper?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Stay—The Doctor may come in; but not Sir George. Mind, on your life, not Sir George!—Come, sir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) This sudden change is mysterious. Here is concealment.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Come, come.

div3.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I purtest, it has put me in such a fluster that I am quite all of a twitter!

div3.stage: Enter SIR GEORGE followed by DR. GOSTERMAN.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Come along, Doctor! Make haste Where is Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: In her own room.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is she worse?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: No, sir; much better: but she must not be disturbed.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I must see her.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Indeed, sir, I can let nobody in but the Doctor.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why so? Is not the gentleman I left here now with her?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: I suppose so, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: And I not admitted?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: On no account whatever.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He allowed, and I excluded! Indeed, I shall attend the Doctor.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Upon my honor, sir, you must not.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Upon my honor, I will! My rival shall not escape me!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ah ha! De rifal! Ha, ha, ha! Dat is coot! De young fer dat vas mit Laty Shane vas make you shealousy? Ha, ha, ha! Dat is coot! Bote dat is as noting at all. I shall tell you de someting mystery. He vas no yentlemans. Ah ha! He vas a vomans.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A woman!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. He vas make acquaintance mit me, und I vas make acquaintance mit him; und he vas make faint, und I vas tie loose de neck bandt, und den! Ah ha! I vas discober de mans vas a vomans!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You astonish me!

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, sair. I vas make astonish myself.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.p: Won't you go to my lady, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p:
Ya, my tear. Let me do. Laty Shane is fery pad; und I shall af de essence, und de cream, und de balsam, und de syrup, und de electric, und de magnetic, und de mineral, und de vegetable,
und de air, und de earse, und de sea, und all, &c. [Exit; gabbling.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I should never have suspected a woman! A stout, tall, robust figure! And for what purpose disguise herself? That may be worth enquiry. I will wait and if possible have another look at the lady.

div3.head: SCENE IX. Enter LORD VIBRATE, and MR. THOMPSON.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Two hundred and forty pounds! 'Tis a very large sum, Mr. Thompson.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: So large, my lord, that I have no means of paying it. I must languish out my life in a prison.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No, Mr. Thompson, no: you shall not do that. I will—And yet—Two hundred—A prison—I don't know what to say. If I pay this money for you, I shall but encourage all around me to run in debt.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: It is a favour too great for me to hope.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You are a worthy man, and a prison is a bad place—I—you—Pray what is your opinion, Sir George? Is it not dangerous for a man to have the character of being charitable?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No doubt, my lord! It is the very certain way for his house to be besieged by beggars!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: The master who pays the debts of one domestic makes himself the debtor of all the rest.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
He changes a set of servants into a set
of duns! He first encourages them to be extravagant, and then makes it incumbent upon himself to pay for their follies and vices! He not only bribes them to be idle, and insolent, but to waste his property as well as their own!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: It is, as you say, a very serious case. I—I am sorry for your misfortune, Mr. Thompson—very sorry—but—really—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Misfortune! What misfortune?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He has foolishly been bound for his sister's husband; and must go to prison for the debt.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To prison?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: You have shewn me how dangerous it would be for me to interfere.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Very true: very true.—He has lived with your lordship several years?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He has; and I esteem him highly.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: A worthy man, whom it would be no disgrace to call your friend?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: None. Still, however, consequences must be weighed. I must take time to consider. 'Tis folly to act in a hurry.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Very true—caution—caution—Is it a large sum?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: No less than two hundred and forty pounds!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Caution is a very excellent thing—Two hundred and forty—A fine virtue—Two—I would advise your lordship to it by all means—hundred and forty— (Looks round) Will you permit me just to write a short memorandum: a bit of a note? (Goes to a table) I must send to a certain place. (Writes) Excuse me a moment.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What can be done in this affair, Mr. Thompson?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Nothing, my lord. I am resigned. When I assisted my brother, I did no more than my duty. Those who lock me up in a prison may, for aught I know, do theirs: yet, though they are at liberty and I shall be confined, I would neither change duties nor hearts with them. (Going.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Harkye! Harkye! Mr. Thompson! Will you just desire this to be taken as it is directed? (Aside to him) Don't say a word: 'tis a draft on my banker. Discharge your debt; and be silent—You are very right, my lord: we cannot be too considerate; lest, by mistaken benevolence, we should encourage vice.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Sir George! My lord!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why now will you not oblige me, Mr. Thompson? Pray let that be delivered as it is directed. You surely will not deny me such a favor—For you know, my lord, if we give—

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Indeed, I—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Will you begone? Will you begone? (Pushes him kindly off▪—If we give without—without—

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Poor fellow! I suppose he is afraid of being taken.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh! Is that it?—If we give, I say, with—too—Pshaw! I have lost the thread of my argument.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I must own, this is a dubious case. Perhaps I ought to pay the money. (Calls) Mr. Thompson!—I don't think I ought to let him go to prison. What shall I do, Sir George?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Whatever your lordship thinks best.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: But there is the difficulty!—Mr. Thompson! He is gone. How foolish this is now! (As he is going off) Harry! Run after Mr. Thompson, and call him back. One would think a man going to prison would like me be wise enough to doubt, and take time to consider of it.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir George, I am very angry. I have been waiting an age, expecting you would come and give your opinion on my masquerade dress.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why did not your ladyship put it on?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: On, indeed? It has been on and off twenty times! I have sent it to have some alteration. Beside it is growing late: masks will be calling in on you, in their way to the Opera-house, and you not at home to receive them!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I ask ten thousand pardons, but you know I am the most thoughtless creature on earth.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: So I would have you. Were you like the sober punctual Mr. Delaval, I should hate you. But then—

div3.head: SCENE XI.
div3.stage: DELAVAL returning from LADY JANE'S apartment.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: (Aside) Here the wretch comes!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) So, so! now I shall interrogate the lady. She has a very masculine air! (Delaval bows to Lady Vibrate) A tolerable bow that, for a woman!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p:
(Aside) He wishes, I suppose, to sermonize
me: but I shall not give him an opportunity—Are you coming, Sir George?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) Ha!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I will follow your ladyship in a minute.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) I was right! It is he!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) She eyes me very ferociously!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I shall just call in upon you: or, if not, we shall meet afterward. I expect you to be very whimsical and satiric upon all my friends; so pray put on your best humour. Grave airs, you know, are my aversion. [Exit.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Aside) That was intended for me. Now for my gentleman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) She really has a very fierce look! A kind of threatening physiognomy; and would make no bad Grenadier.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I understand, your name is Sir George Versatile?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) A bass voice too!—At your service, sir; or madam; I really cannot tell which.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Cannot!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, I cannot upon my soul! (Aside) A devilish black chin!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I have an account to settle with you, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Have you? (Aside) What the plague can she mean?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: When can I find you at leisure, and alone?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes, sir; alone.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Must this account then be privately settled, madam?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I beg your pardon! Sir, since you prefer it.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: If you know me, sir, your insolence is but a confirmation of the baseness of your character!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I beg a million of pardons! I really do not know you.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Then, sir, when you do, you will find cause to be a little more serious.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) What a Joan of Arc it is! There is danger she should knock me down.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Be pleased to name your time.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside) Zounds! She insists upon a tête-à-téte!—I hope you will be kind enough to excuse me, but I am just now so pressed for time that I have not a moment to spare. Company is waiting. I must begone to the masquerade. You I presume are for the same place, and are ready dressed. I am your most obedient—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Seizing him) Sir, I insist upon your naming an hour, to-morrow; and an early one.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Why, what the plague!—Here must be some mistake! Permit me to ask, do you know Dr. Gosterman?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Was you not just now in danger of sainting?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Faint? I faint!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It would I think be a very extraordinary thing! But so he told me: with other particulars.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Absurd! Dr. Gosterman has not seen me for several months.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
He said, sir, you were a woman; and
perhaps, from that error, I may have unconsciously provoked you to behaviour which would else have been rather strange. Have I given you any other offence?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes, sir; a mortal one.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mortal!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: And mortal must be the atonement.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: If so, the sooner the better. Let it be immediately.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: No. I have serious concerns to settle. So have you! 'Tis time you should think of things very different from masquerading. Name your hour to-morrow morning; then, take an enemy's advice, retire to your closet, and make your will.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: To whom am I indebted for this high menace, and this haughty warning? Your name, sir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: That you shall know when next we meet: not before.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What age are you, sir?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Age!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Such peremptory heroes are not usually long lived.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You are right, sir; my life is probably doomed to be short. But this is trifling. Name your hour.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: At ten to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The very time I could wish. I will be with you at your own house, insorm you who I am, and, then—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So be it.— [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE XIII. Changes to the house of SIR GEORGE. A suite of apartments richly decorated and numerous masks: some dancing; others passing and repassing.
div3.stage: SIR GEORGE and LADY VIBRATE advance, unmasked.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: What is the matter with you, Sir George? You are suddenly become as dull and almost as intolerable as my lord himself.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I own, I had something on my spirits. But it is gone. Your ladyship's vivacity is an antidote to splenetic fits.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Oh, if you are subject to fits of the spleen, I renounce you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, no! Heigho! Ha, ha, ha! Let me go merrily down the dance of life!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ay! or I will not be your partner.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: As for recollections, retrospective anxieties, and painful thoughts, I I I hate them. They shall not trouble me. For if a man, you know, were to be sprung on a mine to-morrow, ha, ha, ha! it were folly to let that trouble him to-day.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sprung on a mine? You talk wildly!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: True. I am a wild unaccountable non descript. I am any thing, every thing, and soon may be—

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nothing. Strange events are possible; and possible events are strange.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Come, come, cast off this disagreeable humour; and join the masks.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
With all my heart. A mask is an excellent
utensil; and may be worn with a naked face.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: (Retiring) Why don't you come? You used to be all compliance.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So I fear I always shall be. 'Tis my worst virtue. Call it a vice, if you please; and perhaps it is even then my worst.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I really do not comprehend you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No wonder. Man is an incomprehensible animal! But no matter for that. We will be merry still say I—at least till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: (Joins the masks) Yonder is Lady Jane.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Nay then, I am on the wing!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: (Advancing) Whither?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ah! Have I found you again? So much the better! I have been thinking of you this half hour.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Ay? That must have been a prodigious effort!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: To think of one person for so great a length of time.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: True. Were you my bitterest enemy, you could not have uttered a more galling truth. I am glad I have met with you, however.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: So am I. 'Tis my errand here.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You now, I hope, will let me see your face?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I might, perhaps, were it but possible to see your heart.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: No, no: that cannot be. I have no heart.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am sorry for it!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: So am I. But come, I wish to be better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And I wish you to be better acquainted with yourself. You know not half your own good qualities.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! My good qualities? Heigho!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Your fame is gone abroad! Your gallantry, your free humour, your frolics in England and Italy, your—Apropos: I am told, Lady Jane is captivated by the ardour and delicacy of your passion! Is it true?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Are you an inquisitor?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Are you afraid of inquisitors?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: You may. Keep me no longer in this suspense. Let me know who you are?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: An old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Of mine?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Of one who was formerly your friend.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Whom do you mean?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: You must have been a man of uncommon worth; for I have heard him bestow such praises upon you that my heart has palpitated if your name was but mentioned!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Of whom are you talking?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Lord! that you should be so forgetful! That can only have happened since you became a person of fashion: for no man once remembered his friends better. It is true, they were then useful to you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir, I—Be warned! Pursue this no farther.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p:
You little suspected at that time you were on the eve of being a wealthy baronet. Oh
no! And to see how kind and grateful you were to those who loved you! No one would have believed you could so soon have become a perfect man of the mode; and with so polite and easy an indifference so entirely have forgotten all your old acquaintance! I dare say you scarcely remember the late Colonel Delaval.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: His daughter too has utterly slipped your memory?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I insist on knowing who you are!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: How different it was when, your merit neglected, your spirits depressed, and your poverty despised, you groaned under the oppression of an unjust and selfish world! How did your drooping spirits revive by the fostering smiles of the man who first noticed you, took you to his house and heart, and adopted you as his son! Poor Maria! Silly girl, to love as she did! Where is she?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: This is not to be endured!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: What was her offence? You became a baronet! Ay! True, that was her crime. Yet, when your fortunes were low, it was not imputed to you as guilt.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Aside.) Damnation!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p:
Are your new friends more affectionate than your old? Fortune smiles, and so do they. Poor Maria! Has Lady Jane ever heard her name? Will you invite her to your wedding? (Her voice continually faltering.) Do. She should have been your bride: then let her be your bride maid—She is greatly altered—She will be less beautiful—now—than her fair rival. Her birth is not quite so high—but—if a—heart—a heart—
a heart— (Struggling with her feelings sinks into Sir George's arms, and her mask falls off)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Heavens and earth! 'Tis she! Help! 'Tis Maria! Who waits?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Help! Help!—Salts! Hartshorn!—Water! Help!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Bless me! This lady again.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Is she then known to you?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No! Who is she?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Quick! Quick!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Nay but, tell me?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I cannot! Must not!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Must not?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Dare not!—She revives; and, to my confusion, will soon tell you herself. Maria! Are you better, Maria?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I am very faint.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: My carriage is at the door. Will you trust yourself to me?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh yes. I am weak—Very weak, and very foolish! But I shall not long disturb your happiness. I hope soon to be past that.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Past! Oh Maria!—I—have no utterance—Lady Jane, you will presently know of me what to know of myself is—Oh!—No matter. Not then for my sake but for pity, for the love of suffering virtue, be careful of this lady; whom when you know, as soon you must, you will despise and abhor the lunatic, the wretch, that could—Maria—I—I— [Exit abruptly.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: What is the matter? Any accident? Was not that Sir George?—Good God! My sister!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Your sister!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: How comes this? Why this dress? And with that apostate! that wretch! Speak, Maria!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, be more temperate. Your sister's spirits and health ought not to be trifled with by your violence. I do not know, though I think I guess, her story. I hope you have a brother's tenderness for her?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: That shall be shortly seen. A few hours will shew how dear she is to my heart.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I fear you cherish bad passions: such as I never can love, and never will share.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Well, well, Lady Jane, that is not to be argued now. I am a man, and subject to the mistakes of man. There are feelings which can and feelings which cannot be subdued. I must run my course, and take all consequences.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Oh God! In what will they end?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: No more of this, Mr. Delaval. Come with me: lead your sister to my carriage. She shall be under my care. She can inspire those sympathies which your too stubborn temper seems to despise.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed, you wrong me! [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I. MARIA in her proper dress, LADY JANE and LUCY, FOOTMEN waiting. Breakfast equipage on the table.

sp.speaker: LADY JANE.
sp.p: REMOVE those things. We have done.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: What is it o'clock?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Just struck ten, ma'am.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Lady Vibrate is a sad rake! She did not leave the masquerade till five this morning.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And Sir George not there!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: After the discovery of last night, could you suppose he would be seen revelling at such a place?

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I dread another and more horrible cause! My brother!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, you know, slept in this house.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: But he has been out these two hours!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: What then, ma'am? Is not Mr. Williams on the watch? You know, ma'am, you may trust Mr. Williams with your life.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: If all were safe, he would be back.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Pray calm your spirits.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but Mr. Williams must have been here before this, if something fatal had not happened!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: I am sure, ma'am, you frighten me to death!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Aside) Her terrors are but too well founded!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: (Footsteps without) What noise is that?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Bless me!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: See who it is!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: (After opening the door) Law, ma'am! I declare it is Mr. Williams!

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Williams! Every thing is right: is not it? All is as it should be?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: That is more than I know.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Why then the worst is past.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: No, ma'am: I can't say that, either.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Nay but, what news do you bring? Speak.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why you know my master last night made enquiries how to find the chambers of Counsellor Demur: so, when he went out this morning, I observed your directions and followed him. He went to the Counsellor's, in Lincoln's Inn; and there I left him and hurried away to Sir George's, to enquire and hear all I could: though it was rather unlucky that I was not acquainted in the family.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Did not you make use of my name?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Oh yes, my lady. Beside, servants your ladyship knows are not so suspicious as their masters: they soon become friendly together: so in five minutes Sir George's valet and I were on as intimate a footing as we could wish.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: And what did he say? Tell me.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why, ma'am, he said that Sir George did not leave his own house last night, after the fainting of the young gentleman.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That was you, you know, ma'am.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p:
And, what is more, that he did not go to bed; but walked up and down the room till
daylight in the morning; and then called I don't know how often to warn the servants that he should not be at home to any body whatever, except to a strange gentleman.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Why yes, ma'am, according to the description, it could be nobody else.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: And at what hour was Mr. Delaval to be there?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: (Aside) Zooks! I forgot to ask—That, that, my lady, I did not learn. So, this being all the servants told me, I ran post haste to make my report to you.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: The worst I foreboded will happen!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Perhaps it will be best for me to go back to Sir George's, wait for the arrival of my master, and, if he should come, hasten away as fast as I can to inform you of it.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That is a good thought, Mr. Williams! Is not it, madam? A very good thought, indeed! Don't you think it is, my lady?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: I know not what we can do better.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Nay but, while Williams is bringing us the intelligence, every thing we most dread may happen.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Dear! So it may!

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Suppose then, madam, I should stay at my post; and dispatch Sir George's valet to you with the news?

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: Well, that is the best thought of all! I am sure you will own it is, madam.

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: We must resolve; or, while we are deliberating—

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: Merciful God! Run, Williams! Fly! Save my brother! Save Sir George!

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Succeed but in this, and command all we have to give.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I will do my best.

sp.speaker: LU.
sp.p: That I am sure he will. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE III. Changes to the house of SIR GEORGE.—SIR GEORGE walking in perturbation of mind. After some time he looks at his watch.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: He will soon be here—Five minutes—but five minutes and then— (Walks again, throws himself on a sofa, takes up a book, tosses it away and rises) What is man's first duty? To be happy. Short sighted fool! The happiness of this hour is the misery of the next! (Again walks and looks at his watch) What is life? A tissue of follies! Inconsistencies! Joys that make reason weep, and sorrows at which wisdom smiles. Pshaw! There is not between ape and oyster so ridiculous or so wretched a creature as man. (Walks) Oh Maria! (Again consulting his watch) I want but a few seconds. My watch perhaps is too fast. (Rings)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Has nobody yet been here?

sp.speaker: FOOT.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis the time to a minute. (Loud knocking) Fly! If it be the person I have described, admit him. [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Now let the thunder strike!

div3.head: SCENE IV. DELAVAL introduced. They salute.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Good morning, sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You recollect me?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I have been anxious for your coming. Your menace lives in my memory; and I shall be glad to know the name of him who has threatened such mortal enmity.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: A little patience will be necessary. I must preface my proceedings with a short story.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I shall be all attention. Please to be seated. Wave ceremony, and to the subject— (They sit) Now, sir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: About six years ago, a certain youth came up from college; poor, and unprotected. He was a scholar, pleasing in manner, warm and generous of temper, of a respectable family, and seemed to possess the germ of every virtue.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Hear me on: my praises will not be tedious. Chance made him known to a man who desired to cherish his good qualities; and the purse, the experience, and the power of his benefactor, such as they were, he profited by to the utmost. Received as a son, he soon became dear to the family: but most dear to the daughter of his friend; whose tender age and glowing affections made her apt to admire the virtues she heard her father so ardently praise, and encourage. You are uneasy?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Be pleased to continue.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
The assiduities of the youth to gain her
heart were unabating; and his pretensions, poor and unknown as he then was, were not rejected. The noble nature of his friend scorned to make his poverty his crime. Why do you bite your lip? Was it not generous?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Firmly) Was it not?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Certainly! Nothing could—equal the—generosity.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The health of his benefactor was declining fast; and the only thing required of the youth was that he should qualify himself for the cares of life, by some profession. He therefore entered a student in the Temple; and the means were furnished by his protector, till the end was obtained. Was not this friendship?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The lady, almost a child when first he knew her, increased in grace and beauty faster than in years. Sweetness and smiles played upon her countenance. She was the delight of her friends, the admiration of the world, and the coveted of every eye. Lovers of fortune and fashion contended for her hand: but she had bestowed her heart—had bestowed it on a—Sit still, sir; I shall soon have done. I am coming to the point. Five years elapsed; during which the youth received every kindness friendship could afford, and every proof chaste affection had to give. These he returned with promises and protestations that seemed too vast for his heart. I would say for his tongue—Are you unwell, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Go on with your tale.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
His benefactor, feeling the hand of death steal on, was anxious to see the two persons dearest
to his heart happy before he expired; and the marriage was determined on, the day fixed, and the friends of the family invited. The intended bridegroom appeared half frantic with his approaching bliss. Now, sir, mark his proceeding. In this short interval, by sudden and unexpected deaths, he becomes the heir to a title and large estate. Well! Does he not fly to the arms of his languishing friend? Does he not pour his new treasures and his transports into the lap of love? Coward and monster!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Both starting up) Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Viler than words can paint! Having robbed a family of honor, a friend of peace, and an angel of every human solace, he fled, like a thief, and concealed himself from immediate contempt and vengeance in a foreign country. But contempt and vengeance have at length overtaken him: they beset him: they face him at this instant. The friend he wronged is dead: but the son of that friend lives, and I am he.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: 'Tis as I thought!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You are—I will not defile my lips by telling you what you are.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: I own that what I have done—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Forbear to interrupt me, sir. You have nothing to plead, and much to hear. First say, did my sister, by any improper conduct, levity of behaviour, or fault or vice whatever, give you just cause to abandon her?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: None! None! Her purity is only exceeded by her love.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
Then how, barbarian, how had you the heart to disgrace the family and endanger the life of a woman whose sanctified affection would have
embraced you in poverty, pestilence, or death; and who, had she possessed empires, would have bestowed them with an imperial affection?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Sir, if you ask, Have I committed errors? call them crimes if you will, Yes. If you demand, Will I justify them? No. If you require me to atone for them, here is my heart: you have wrongs to revenge, strike; and, if you can, inflict a pang greater than any it yet has known.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Justice is not to be disarmed by being braved. To the question. It can be no part of your intention, and certainly not of mine, that you should marry my sister. Something very different must be done.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What? Name it?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: You must give me an acknowledgment, written and signed by yourself, that you have basely and most dishonorably injured, insulted and betrayed Maria Delaval: and this paper, immediately as I leave your house, I shall publish in every possible way; till my sister shall be so appeased, and honor so satiated, that vengeance itself shall cry, Hold!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Written by me! Published! No. I will sign no such paper.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p:
So I supposed; and the alternative follows. Here I am: nor will I quit you, go where you will, till you shall consent to retire with me to some place from which one of us must never return. Should I be the victor, flight, banishment from my native country, and the bitterest recollections of the villanies of man, must be the fate of me and my sister. If I fall, you then may triumph and she languish and die unrevenged. This,
or the written acknowledgment. Consider, and chuse.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: What can I answer? The paper you shall not have. My life you are welcome to: take it.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Have you not brought disgrace enough on my family? Would you make me an assassin? My sister and my father loved you. Let me, if possible, feel some little return of respect for you.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Having wronged the sister, would you have me murder the brother? Already the most guilty of men, would you make me the worst of fiends? Though an enemy, be a generous one.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Plausible sophist! The paper, sir: or, man to man and arm to arm, close the scene of my dishonor, or your own. The written acknowledgment. Determine. (Walks away and views the pictures)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Apart) Why, ay! 'Tis come home! I have sought it, deserved it, 'tis fallen, and the rock must crush the reptile!—Then welcome ruin. The sword must decide. (Goes to take his sword, but stops) The sword? What! Betray the sister and assassinate the brother? Oh God! And such a brother! Stern, but noble minded: indignant of injury, peerless in affection, and proud of a sister whom the world might worship; but whom I, worthless wretch, in levity and pride of heart, have abandoned. (Aloud) Mr. Delaval!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Have you resolved to sign?

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The written acknowledgment!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
My behaviour to your sister is—what I cannot endure to name—'Tis hateful! 'Tis—infamous!
My obligations to your most excellent father, the respect you have inspired me with, and my love for Maria—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Insolent! Insufferable meanness! The paper, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Angry though you are, Mr. Delaval, you must hear me. I say, my love, my adoration of Maria has but increased my guilt. It has made me dread her contempt. I durst not face the angel whom I had so deeply injured.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Artifice! Evasion! Cowardice!—Your signature!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Snatching up his sword from the table) You shall have it. Follow me.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Stopping short) Hold, Mr. Delaval. Justice is on your side. If your firmness be not a savage spirit of revenge, if you do not thirst for blood, you will feel my only resource will be to fall on your sword. I cannot lift my arm against you.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Then sign the acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p:
Can you in the spirit even of an enemy ask it? Do you not already despise me enough? Think for a moment: am I the only man that ever erred? Is it so wonderful that a giddy youth, whose habitual failing was compliance, by sudden accident elevated to the pinnacle of fortune, surrounded by proud and selfish relations of whose approbation I was vain, is it so strange that I should be overpowered by their dictates, and yield to their intreaties? Your friendship or my death is now the only alternative. Suppose the latter: will it honor you among men? At the man of blood the heart of man revolts! Will it endear you to
Maria? Kind forgiving angel, and hateful to myself as her affection makes me, I last night found that affection still as strong, still as pure, as in the first hour of our infant loves. Lady Jane—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Forbear to name her! 'Tis profanation from your lips! No more casuistry! No subterfuge! The paper!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Can no motives—

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: None!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: My future life, my soul, shall be devoted to Maria.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The paper!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Obdurate man! (Reflects a moment) You shall have it. (Goes to the table to write, during which Delaval remains deep in thought and much agitated) Here, sir! since you will not be generous, let me be just. 'Tis proper I remove every taint of suspicion from the deeply wronged Maria.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: (Reads with a faltering voice) I George Versatile, once poor and dependent, since vain fickle and faithless, do under my hand acknowledge I have perfidiously—broken my pledged promise—to the most deserving—lovely—and (Begins in much agitation to tear the paper.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Damn it—I can't—I can't speak. Here! Here! (Striking his bosom.)

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval?

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: My brother!

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: (Falls on his neck) Can it be? My friend!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: This stubborn temper—always in extremes! The tiger, or the child.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Oh no! 'Twas not to be forgiven! Best of men!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Well, well: we are friends.

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Everlastingly! Brothers!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Yes; brothers.

div3.head: SCENE V. Enter WILLIAMS in great haste.

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, but Lady Jane and your sister are below. They insist on coming up, and the servants are afraid to—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Maria! Let us fly! [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE VI. The apartments of LORD VIBRATE.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my coot laty: dat vas efery vordt so true as vat I say. I vas discober it vas a vomans; und Sair Shorge, und my Laty Shane, und de vaiting vomans vas discober to me all as vat I say more.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ay, ay! That was the reason Sir George was not at the masquerade.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Ya, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I observed he was in a strange moody humour.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: My Lordt Fiprate vas fery mosh amazement, ven I vas make him discober all as vat I vas make discober mit my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Sir George has behaved very improperly.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p:
So, so, so! All I foreboded has come to pass! The day is slipped away, a new one is
here, and every possibility of recovering the estate is gone!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Do you laugh?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I do, indeed!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is your daughter's loss the subject of your mirth?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No, no; not her loss, but your positive determination to prove I did not know you! Ha, ha, ha! When I told you that even that motive would not be strong enough, how you stormed! "But it will, my lady! But it won't, my lord! I say it will, my lady! I say it won't, my lord!" Ha, ha, ha! Will you believe that I know you now?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What shall I do? Advise me, Doctor.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: I vas adfice, my coot Lordt, dat you shall do efery ting as vat you please.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Ay, think: ask advice. Ha, ha, ha! Now that you can do nothing, the enquiry will be very amusing.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Well, Thompson, what says Counsellor Demur? Has the time absolutely elapsed?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Absolutely, my lord.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: How wisely your lordship doubts, before you decide! Hay, Doctor?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: I have good news, nevertheless.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Good news? Speak! Of what kind?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The honesty of the opposite party.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, the holder of the land?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Yes, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Which way? Explain!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: He has engaged to Mr. Demur, I being present, that, if your lordship will only shew the legality of your late title, he will resign the estate.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: It cannot be! The last purchaser is in India.

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The last purchaser is dead; and it has descended to one whom you, my lord and lady, little suspect to be its possessor.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval resign it on exhibiting the legality of my title?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: He will, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did he make no conditions?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, did he not mention Lady Jane?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Her name did escape his lips; but rising passion, and, if I rightly read his heart, emotions of the most delicate sensibility immediately closed them: as if he would not endure the love he bore her to be profaned by any the slightest semblance of barter and sale.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What do you say to that, Lady Vibrate? What do you say to that?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: The proceeding is honorable, I own.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did I not always tell you Mr. Delaval was a man of honor?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You tell me, my lord? Why you were going to challenge him yesterday morning!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: He is no such weathercock as your favorite, Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You mistake: Sir George is no favorite of mine. Is he, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yust as vat you say, my coot laty.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: What, he did not come to make a buffoon of himself, for your diversion, at the masquerade last night! Hay, Doctor?

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas all yust as vat you say, my coot lordt.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: His perfidious treatment of Miss Delaval is unpardonable.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat vas pad! Fery pad, inteet!

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Ay ay! He has plenty of words, but he has no heart.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Dat is pad! Fery pad inteet!

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: Pardon me, my lord: Sir George may have committed mistakes, but to the goodness of his heart I am a witness.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: By his benevolence, I was yesterday relieved from the disgrace and the horrors of a prison.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: He paid a debt, which, had I been confined, I never could have discharged; and, for this unexpected act of humanity, he would not suffer so much as my thanks.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Did Sir George pay the two hundred and forty pounds, Mr. Thompson?

sp.speaker: THOM.
sp.p: The note, which he pretended to write and send by me, was a draft on his banker for three hundred.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Why he confirmed all my arguments against it; and added twice as many of his own.

sp.speaker: DR.
sp.p: Sair Shorge vas alvay make agréable. Dat vas his vay.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: I own, however, I am still more surprised at the unexampled generosity of Mr. Delaval.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Where is your master, Mr. Williams?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: They are all coming, my lady.

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: Who is coming?

sp.speaker: WILL.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, Lady Jane, Miss Delaval, and Sir George. There has been sad work! But it is all over, and they are now so happy! Here they are!

div3.head: SCENE THE LAST. Enter Mr. DELAVAL leading LADY JANE, and SIR GEORGE with MARIA, followed by LUCY.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Mr. Delaval, I have great obligations to you. Thompson has been telling me of your disinterested equity.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: The obligation, my lord, was mine. Your lordship well knows that the first of obligations is to be just.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Well, well; but the estate you are so willing to resign will still, I hope, be yours.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Nay, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Dubious as all things are, that is a subject on which I protest I do not believe I shall ever have any doubts. What say you, Lady Jane? (Irony) But now I have my doubts again.

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: (Eagerly) What doubts, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: I doubt whether you understand me?

sp.speaker: LADY J.
sp.p: Would your lordship teach me to dissemble?

sp.speaker: LORD V.
sp.p: Um—I doubt whether that would be much for your good.

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: I hope Lady Vibrate will not oppose our union?

sp.speaker: LADY V.
sp.p: No, Mr. Delaval. Your last generous action has charmed me; and Sir George—

sp.speaker: SIR G.
sp.p: Has declined in your good opinion. But you cannot think so ill of me as I do of myself; and, if ever again I should recover my own self respect, I shall be indebted for it to this best of men, and to this most incomparable and affectionate of women!

sp.speaker: MAR.
sp.p: My present joys are inexpressible!

sp.speaker: DEL.
sp.p: Which my impetuous indignation threatened▪ for ever to destroy. (Comes forward) How dangerous are extremes! Sometimes we doubt, and indecision is our bane: at others, hurried away by the sudden impulse of passion, our course is marked with misery. One man is too compliant: another too intractable. Yet happiness is the aim of all. Since then all are so liable to be misled, let gentle forbearance, indulgent thoughts, and a mild forgiving spirit, be ever held as the sacred duties of man to man.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.byline: SPOKEN BY MR. QUICK, AND MRS. MATTOCKS.
div1.stage: (As Mr Pope concludes and is preparing to low to the audience, Mr Quick with some importance comes forward.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: HOLD, Mr. Pope! Please to give place to me:
'Tis my part to conclude the comedy.
Hem! Hem! (Begins a grave and stately how.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: (Eagerly advancing.) Yours, Mr. Quick? I beg you'll hold your tongue!
All Epilogues of right to me belong.
You tease the audience, sir; and put me out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: Tease? Humph! Permit me, madam, there to doubt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: Your part is over, now; your doubts are ended.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: Would that they were! (To the audience.) Say, friends, are you offended?
Or are you pleas'd? Which way do you incline?
The author has his doubts; and I have mine;
Pronounce our doom: relieve us from our pain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: (Laughs.) Look at those dismal features and refrain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: Should it be fatal, hear, oh hear, our pleadings!
Grant an arrest of judgment: stay proceedings:
I move the court—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: You move? Stand back! I'll wait no longer.
I tell you once again I am th' Epilogue monger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: What do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: You! There's reason ample▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Q.
sp.l: (Retiring.) I beg, sirs, you'll not follow her example.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.l: The hypocrite! Well, well, I'm glad he's gone:
For now the pleadings will be all my own.
The author hopes I'll advocate his play.
Heaven help the man! What would he have me say?
Something about the anxious months he spent,
His garret traversing his brain intent
On this, and that, and t'other; action, plot,
Wit, humour, passion; and the lord knows what!
And tell how difficult it was to write
The charming nonsense you have heard to-night!—
Poor fool! When he suppos'd his work complete,
He thought he had achiev'd a mighty feat!
Nay he protests that earth and heaven he'd move,
Could he but pen what you might well approve.
The man speaks fair; is tolerably civil:
Then, since an author's only a poor devil,
Doom him to what will give us all delight:
Make him repeat his follies every night.
